Harry AER he runs the he's the director
of the human genome program human
genetics program at enu medical school
he is a professor of Pediatrics
pathology and Medicine there and he has
a wide range of interests which he's
pursued in his laboratory he's worked on
the genetics of prostate cancer and
other forms of cancer he's worked on
genetics of ancestry particularly in
Jewish and Latino populations he's
worked on the genetics of male sexual
development and he's been very involved
in issues involving the fair use of

York in which he's been involved in
every piece of legislation that's ending
or enacted that has to do with genetic
testing with reproductive technology and
human cloning so welcome Dr

AER so I'd like to thank Paul Hoffman
and his fellow organizers of big think
uh for inviting me to participate this
evening as Francis Collins understudied
uh this invitation has left me wondering
what whether there might be an NIH
directorship in my future or whether
I'll be left with the happy fate of
being a medical geneticist free to
pursue my own research leads there are
three areas that I currently explore the
first is the genetic control of male
sexual
development normally a switch on the Y
chromosome turns on a pathway that
causes half of us in the population to
develop testes male reproductive
structures and to develop as men but
this switch or its Downstream relays may
go a causing affected individuals to
develop as women or to have ambiguous
sexual
development these people with disorders
of sexual development present the
experiments of nature that we
geneticists so value because they
represent an opportunity for
understanding the whole Cascade of genes
in the male sexual development pathway
in my lab we've recently identified one
of these regulatory genes for male
sexual development and we think that it
is not a relay for the master regulator
rather it regulates the on switch for
the master
regulator we studi the populations of uh
Jewish and Hispanic Latina people uh
together these groups comprise 12 and
20% of the population of New York City
we're tracing the Jewish diaspora back
and forth across the Mediterranean Basin
into Europe and into the new world Jews
form their own distinctive genetic
clusters with each group of the diaspora
forming its own
subcluster Puerto Ricans and Dominicans
are for the most part the variable
descendants of Europeans and Africans
whereas Mexicans ecuadorians and
Colombians are the descendants of Native
Americans and
Europeans we're using methods that
recognize this ADM miixed ancestry to
map genes for traits such as
susceptibility to breast cancer in fact
my NYU collaborators and I are working
to develop predictive genetic test for
breast
prostate uh and prostate cancers uh as
well as uh melanoma envisioning a day
perhaps 5 years hence when it will be
possible to perform a test in which the
results will be reproducible and
meaningful if we thought that the tests
that are offered by directed consumer
genetic testing companies were valid
then we would use them at our cancer
genetics risk evaluation program where
we see nearly a thousand people each
year assessing their risks of breast
ovarian and colon
cancers when a new genetic test is
introduced into clinical practice we're
looking for three things analytical
validity clinical validity and clinical
utility the tests that are performed in
my clinical genetics laboratory and in
the other Laboratories that I use to
assess the risk for my patients at NYU
meet all of these
criteria let's look at each of these in
turn analytical validity is the ability
of a test to accurately and reliably
measure the genotype of
interest for many DNA chips the call
rates are in the range of 98 to
99.9% that sounds great but let's throw
in some numbers this means on a DNA trip
with a million probes 1,000 to 20,000
results are being missed that's okay in
my research lab but it sure isn't in my
clinical lab where I have to guarantee
to to the patients and to the Department
of Health that I can provide complete
results to every patient now let's throw
in the recent computer software and we

chip core facility at Yale that the
false positive rate is
1% this is a false positive rate
anywhere on the trip not in the probe
for breast cancer or type two

associated disorder it must be great
no uh why else would these directed uh
consumer companies be offering uh
testing to Consumers

even the Ardent proponents of genetic

still at the early stages of identifying
the full list of susceptibility
associated
variants we know from research studies
that most common diseases diabetes
various cancers and heart disease are
caused by multiple Gene variants acting
together in with environmental factors
the studies that are now identifying
these factors in their interactions are
only now being
conducted and their validation for

disease bloggers who have used direct to
Consumer genetic testing have written

often state that the services offered

but seriously folks if you learn that

attack or colon cancer or type 2

feel rather foolish when he said but

out of this
or would he start ordering tests a a

Physicians
practices this raises the third issue of
clinical utility or the balance of
associated risks and
benefits Jeffrey dren from the New
England Journal has written this is the
arena in which there are virtually no
data on the health impact of genomewide
analysis there are very few
observational studies and almost no
clinical trials that demonstrate the
risks and benefits associated with
screening for individual Gene variants
let alone testing for many hundreds of
thousands of
variants and what might we do and what
might those recommendations be lose
weight eat better stop smoking exercise
more who needs a $1,000 genetic test to
tell her to engage in lifestyle changes
that will have broad health effects
suppose she learns she is at increased
risk for breast cancer as women who are
brca1 carriers do would she take drugs
that would put her into menopause or
have her breast removed to lower the
wrist or would she just worry her way
from one mamogram to the
next so what can we do now that is
reasonable get diagnosed if you have a
genetic disease get treated and learn
about it knowledge is power
learn about your family history if based
on your family history you were at high
risk for colon cancer heart disease
blood clots or a host of other
conditions consult with a medical
geneticist there may be a specific
genetic test that is appropriate for you
get ter carrier testing before marriage
before pregnancy during
pregnancy get the other tests that are
appropriate for people in your stage of
the life cycle learn your risks and act
you don't need a $1,000 genetic test to
Spur you into
action now the purveyors of directed
consumer genetic testing would say that
this is the old-fashioned Neanderthal
Lite practice of medical
genetics but I would beg to
diff we medical geneticists and genetic
counselors are the age of
progress uh of genetic Discovery we have
reinvented our profession many times and
we are leading the way to discovering
the an itical validity the clinical
validity and the clinical utility of new
genetic
tests we admire the community activism
that brought us new treatments for HIV
AIDS expanded genetic screening for
breast cancer via mamography and
validated new genetic testing for many
conditions we want to build a bridge to
somewhere we are looking forward to that
day when a 61-year-old man walks into
our office with a pill rolling treamer
and we can insert his DNA sequence micro
disk into our genetic risk reader and it
will state with high likelihood that he
has Parkinson disease type 7 moreover it
will tell us that he would benefit from
treatment with drug C because of his
personal risk benefit genetic
ratio that day is not far off and it
will be coming one disease at a time in
the meantime I fear that the purveyors
of direct to consumer genetic testing
where their faulty claims will scare
away our patients and betray The
public's trust in medical genetics thank
you very much for listening
